metadata.case_name: India Sugars and Refineries Ltd. & Salar Jung Sugar Mills Ltd. v. State of Mysore
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 2002 to 2005 and 2014 to 2017 of 1968

facts.text: Appellants are India Sugars and Refineries Ltd. situated at Hospet in Bellary District, Mysore, and Salar Jung Sugar Mills Ltd. situated at Munirabad in Raichur District, Mysore.
India Sugars and Refineries Ltd. challenged demands and collections for purchase tax and penalty on sugarcane purchases from 1 April 1962 to 30 June 1967, seeking refund.
Salar Jung Sugar Mills Ltd. challenged similar demands for period 1 July 1963 to 30 June 1967.
In fifties, States levied cess on sugarcane brought into sugar factories premises.
Supreme Court in Diamond Sugar Mills v. State of U.P. (1961) 3 SCR 242 held U.P. Sugarcane Cess Act, 1956 beyond State competence.
Sugarcane Cess Validation Act, 1961 passed by Parliament validating pre-1961 cess collections.
Mysore Act No. 11 of 1961 included sugarcane at Serial No. 11-A in Third Schedule to Mysore Sales Tax Act, 1957 at 15% tax on purchases by last dealer.
Central Government made Sugarcane Control Order, 1955 under s.3 Essential Commodities Act, 1955, fixing minimum price, regulating supply.
Rule 125-B Defence of India Rules introduced 1963-10-04, empowering reservation of areas, fixing quantities, requiring agreements.
Sugar notified essential under Rule 125-B on 1963-09-26; powers delegated to States on 1963-10-07.
Mysore Sugarcane Regulation of Supply Order, 1963 made 1963-11-14, reserving areas for factories including appellants, requiring 95% supply, agreements.
Sugarcane Control Order, 1955 amended 1964-02-14, adding powers to reserve areas, fix quantities, require agreements.
Powers under clause 4 delegated to State Governments including Mysore on 1964-02-20.
Mysore Sugarcane Regulation of Supply Munirabad Order, 1965 made 1965-01-15 for Salar Jung, crushing capacity 1000 tons/day, 1,50,000 tons/year, 95% supply.
Sugarcane Control Order, 1966 made 1966-07-16 repealing 1955 Order.
Mysore Sugarcane Regulation of Distribution Munirabad Order, 1966 for Salar Jung.
Appellants filed writ petitions under Art 226 in Mysore High Court seeking prohibition on levy/collection of purchase tax on sugarcane, refund.
Mysore High Court dismissed writs on 1968-04-16; appeals by certificate.
Agreements entered between factories and growers as required by orders.

legal_issues.text: Whether there was a purchase and sale of sugarcane given statutory controls on price, quantity, areas, requiring agreements, lacking mutual assent.
Whether appellants are dealers within s.2(k) Mysore Sales Tax Act, 1957.
Whether levy of 15% purchase tax discriminatory under Article 14 due to different rates in different States.

petitioner_arguments.text: No mutual assent between appellants and growers; transaction by operation of statutes only; no freedom to buy/sell; elements of sale per Sale of Goods Act lacking.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sale of Goods Act; Entry 54 List II; Gannon Dunkerley; New India Sugar Mills

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellants not dealers under s.2(k) Mysore Sales Tax Act as sugarcane purchased for manufacture of sugar, not resale.
15% tax discriminatory under Art 14 as rates differ across States; cannot pass on tax to sugar purchasers.

respondent_arguments.text: Transaction essence of purchase/sale with mutual assent; growers can bargain higher price; agreements decisive; controls do not negate contract.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Sugarcane Control Orders; Indian Steel & Wire Products; Andhra Sugars

respondent_arguments.text: Appellants carry on business of buying sugarcane, hence dealers even if used in manufacture.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.2(k) Mysore Sales Tax Act; State of AP v. Abdul Bakshi & Bros.

respondent_arguments.text: All Mysore factories treated equally; different State rates justified by local conditions; inability to pass on tax irrelevant.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Article 14; Tata Iron & Steel v. State of Bihar

court_reasoning.text: Statutory controls on price, areas, quantity do not negate mutual assent or sale; agreements entered with volition; comparable to ration sales; unascertained goods appropriated on delivery/inspection.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Transactions constitute sales within s.2(t) Mysore Sales Tax Act despite regulations for economic planning.

court_reasoning.text: Appellants buy sugarcane in business, convertible to another commodity; hence dealers under s.2(k).
court_reasoning.key_observation: No need to sell same commodity.

court_reasoning.text: Equal treatment within State; inter-State differences justified; tax nature unchanged if not passed on.

holdings.text: Transactions are sales of goods taxable under Mysore Sales Tax Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Diamond Sugar Mills v. State of U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Held State cess invalid, leading to Validation Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co. (Madras) Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Definition of sale requires mutual assent, competency, transfer of property, price.

precedents_cited.case_name: New India Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Sales Tax, Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: No sale where no privity/volition under controls; minority view on implied contract.

precedents_cited.case_name: Indian Steel & Wire Products Ltd. v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Controls do not negate contract if mutual assent present.

precedents_cited.case_name: Andhra Sugars Ltd. v. State of A.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Compulsion by statute does not void sale; grower free to offer.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Rajasthan v. Karamchand Thapar Bros.
precedents_cited.relevance: Controls superimpose on contract; elements of sale present.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chittormal Narain Das v. Commissioner of Sales Tax
precedents_cited.relevance: No volition in wheat levy order.

precedents_cited.case_name: Tata Iron & Steel Co. v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Inability to pass on tax does not alter tax nature.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of A.P. v. Abdul Bakshi & Bros.
precedents_cited.relevance: Dealer if buys commodity even for manufacture.

statutes_cited.name: Mysore Sales Tax Act, 1957
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines dealer and sale; taxes purchase of sugarcane at 15%.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Equality; writs; legislative competence for sales tax.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Sale of Goods Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Passing of property in unascertained goods.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals, upholding Mysore High Court dismissal of writs; levy of purchase tax on sugarcane valid as sales by dealers, no Art 14 violation.

key_quotes.text: The transactions amount to sales within the meaning of the Mysore Sales Tax Act.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on issue of sale despite controls.

key_quotes.text: So long as mutual assent is not completely excluded in any dealing, in law it is a contract.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quoting Indian Steel case; key to rejecting no-assent argument.

key_quotes.text: The combination of all these features indicates that the parties entered into agreement with mutual assent and with volition for transfer of goods in consideration of price.
key_quotes.speaker: court
